title: Statute of limitation for medical bills in California
question: I was admitted to the ER in a hospital and I did not have health insurance. I received medical bills. I phoned the medical provider and a monthly payment plan was set.
answers: 4 years from the date of the last payment

There are different SOLs for different legal theories. Suit on an implied contract is 2 years. Other limits apply to "account stated", "open book account", "quantum meruit", etc.

Are you being contacted by a debt collector? How much are they claiming? I suggest that you not send any money without talking with an attorney. Do not waste your time debating the law with a debt collector.

What is on your credit report? You can get a free copy, once each year, by going to annualcreditreport.com. Avoid the solicitations trying to sell you any sort of credit monitoring service and just get a copy of your credit reports from each of the 3 major bureaus. See if the account is listed, and, if so, by whom, and for what amount.

Yes, the medical provider (or its collection agency) can certainly come back and demand payment. The SOL in CA for written contracts is 4 years (section 337 of the civil procedure code). That said, the SOL is reset every time you make a payment or "reaffirm" the debt. And, the SOL is only an affirmative defense - it doesn't mean you cannot be sued.
